Award.AwardTitle: Field Theoretical Methods in Strongly Interacting, Topological, and Disordered Condensed Matter Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education to develop advanced theoretical tools to tackle problems in areas that include quantum entanglement, topological insulators, the plateau transition in the integer quantum Hall effect, and quantum critical phenomena. Many of the most interesting, or newly emerging phenomena in condensed matter physics cannot be understood in terms of existing paradigms and techniques, and the development of new methods or approaches for their description is often needed. Materials of particular interest include those where electronic behavior is dominated by strong interactions and strong disorder, and those exhibiting topological features. The understanding of such systems is often very challenging due to the limited number of theoretical tools available for their investigation. The focus of the work supported under this award is the development and the application of novel methods and techniques in condensed matter theory, a process that also benefits from recent advances in the mathematical sciences. The PI aims to develop theoretical tools in the context of the study of quantum entanglement and quantum information, topological states of matter and topological insulators, and localization transitions in disordered electronic systems. The methods planned to be employed range from topology, to conformal field theory, the Schramm-Loewner Evolution and the functional renormalization group.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports theoretical research and education aimed at the discovery and study of novel phases of matter. The latter often exhibit completely new phenomena and may possess highly unusual properties that can hold promise to form the basis of future technologies. One recent example is the discovery of topological insulators, which are insulators in the bulk but conductors at the surface. Another example is a notion called non-Abelian statistics, a possible quantum property of electronic materials which has been proposed to form the physical underpinnings of what is known as a fault-tolerant quantum computer whose realization would mark the dawn of an entirely new era of computation. As new phenomena appear in condensed matter physics, the development of novel methods or approaches for their description is often called for. This typically occurs in electronic systems dominated by strong interactions, or by the presence of strong disorder arising from omnipresent sample impurities. The focus of this project is the development and the application of new theoretical tools in condensed matter theory, some of which benefit from recent advances in the mathematical sciences. Today's newly developed methods will belong to the standard repertoire of tools available to the next generation of researchers. This research activity aims to advance fundamental science at the frontiers of condensed matter theory, with the potential to contribute to the development of future technologies. It will also contribute to the training and mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers interacting with the PI on this project. This activity will thus contribute to the education of the next generation of condensed matter theorists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Some of the most unusual and surprising properties of systems composed of very large numbers of quantum mechanical objects interacting with each other (many-body systems) consist in the fact that they can exhibit collective properties and phenomena at macroscopic scales that are entirely unexpected from considerations of the individual objects or constituents. Such unusual collective quantum properties that have more recently attracted significant attention are the emergence of topological properties of a macroscopic quantum system, as well as collective quantum entanglement features that allow for a characterization of the quantum mechanical state of an interacting many-body system through the lens of tools developed in quantum information theory. Much of the work in this project is devoted to questions related to these topics. The following brief summaries aim at highlighting some of that work.

-An overview article, presented as part of the Nobel Symposium 156 - New Forms of Matter: Topological Insulators and Superconductors -  (June 2014, Stockholm), relates to each other three different approaches to the classification of topological insulators and superconductors of non-interacting Fermions, the so-called 10-Fold Way.

-Shortly after the discovery in the 1980ies of Quantum Hall states of electrons moving in strong magnetic fields, Kalmeyer and Laughlin proposed similar ?Bosonic? Quantum Hall states for spins. In the work done under this project, this topological quantum state was shown to be realized in Quantum Spin-Liquids of spin-1/2 spins on a Kagome lattice with a relatively simple local Hamiltonian, subject to time-reversal symmetry breaking. Quantum Entanglement (i.e. Quantum Information) tools were used to uniquely identify the universal topological properties of the ground state of this Hamiltonian.

-When a generic (local) unitary time-evolution operator that possesses no conservation laws repeatedly acts on a quantum state of a many-body system, the resulting state becomes what is known as Volume-Law entangled, meaning that quantum information is encoded non-locally in the state and is essentially inaccessible to local physical probes. The system exhibits Quantum Chaos. The reduced density matrix of the state in a finite region of space then possesses a spectrum that has the same universal properties as a Random Matrix (a property studied in detail as part of this project); the quantum information entropy of this density matrix grows with the volume of the region (Volume Law) and corresponds to the thermodynamic entropy. When, in contrast, the quantum state of the system is measured repeatedly, at random positions and at random time-steps during the time evolution, a continuous phase transition turns out to occur when the quantum measurements occur at a particular non-vanishing sufficiently large finite rate. At large rates of measurement, the quantum state is no longer Volume-Law entangled, but instead Area-Law entangled. The quantum measurements compete with the tendency of the unitary time-evolution to entangle the state and to generate a Volume Law which still prevails at sufficiently small rates of measurement. This represents a phase transition of a kind that was never known before, since it separates a Volume-Law entangled phase from an Area-Law entangled phase: All known (and indeed well-studied) phase transitions either occur at a finite temperature, in which case the two phases separated by the transition are Volume-Law entangled, or occur at zero temperature (Quantum Phase Transition), in which case the transition separates two Area-Law phases. As part of this project, a theoretical framework was developed within which to formulate this completely novel kind of phase transition.

The project has contributed, via training and mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, to the education of young researchers in condensed matter theory.
